<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 278, 232, 294]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 294]]<|/det|>
9709/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 310, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 908, 320]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 908, 345]]<|/det|>

You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 97, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = 12\left(\frac{1}{2} x - 1\right)^{- 4}\). It is given that the curve passes through the point \(P(6, 4)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 129, 146, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 129, 554, 149]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the tangent to the curve at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 129, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 504, 186, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 504, 403, 523]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 77, 94, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = a x^{\frac{1}{2}} - 2x\), where \(x > 0\) and \(a\) is a constant. The curve has a stationary point at the point \(P\), which has \(x\)-coordinate 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 122, 336, 141]]<|/det|>
Find the \(y\)-coordinate of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 122, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 99, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 667, 107]]<|/det|>
The coefficient of \(x^{2}\) in the expansion of \(\left(1 + \frac{2}{p} x\right)^{5} + (1 + px)^{6}\) is 70.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 117, 455, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the possible values of the constant \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 452, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded segment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 344, 92]]<|/det|>
Show that the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[369, 98, 628, 131]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{\sin\theta + \cos\theta} +\frac{1}{\sin\theta - \cos\theta} = 1\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 138, 920, 172]]<|/det|>
may be expressed in the form \(a \sin^2 \theta + b \sin \theta + c = 0\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are constants to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 154, 920, 172]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 148, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 767, 103]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\frac{1}{\sin \theta + \cos \theta} + \frac{1}{\sin \theta - \cos \theta} = 1\) for \(0^\circ \leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 78, 920, 97]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A tool for putting fence posts into the ground is called a 'post-rammer'. The distances in millimetres that the post sinks into the ground on each impact of the post-rammer follow a geometric progression. The first three impacts cause the post to sink into the ground by \(50 \text{mm}\), \(40 \text{mm}\) and \(32 \text{mm}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 900, 153]]<|/det|>
Verify that the 9th impact is the first in which the post sinks less than \(10 \text{mm}\) into the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 150, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
Find, to the nearest millimetre, the total depth of the post in the ground after 20 impacts. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 510, 176, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 510, 803, 529]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest total depth in the ground which could theoretically be achieved. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 603, 92]]<|/det|>
Functions f and g are both defined for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\) and are given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 100, 564, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\operatorname {f}(x) = x^{2} - 4x + 9,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 123, 584, 142]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}(x) = 2x^{2} + 4x + 12.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 164, 455, 183]]<|/det|>
Express \(\operatorname {f}(x)\) in the form \((x - a)^2 + b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 504, 186, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 504, 485, 522]]<|/det|>
Express \(\mathrm{g}(x)\) in the form \(2[(x + c)^2 + d]\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 505, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 655, 92]]<|/det|>
Express \(\mathrm{g}(x)\) in the form \(k\mathrm{f}(x + h)\), where \(k\) and \(h\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 186, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 510, 920, 547]]<|/det|>
Describe fully the two transformations that have been combined to transform the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) to the graph of \(y = \mathrm{g}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 546]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The acute angle between the two tangents at \(B\) is denoted by \(\alpha^{\circ}\), and the scales on the axes are the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 220, 137]]<|/det|>
Find \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 420, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(B\) and \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 584, 529]]<|/det|>
The point \(D\) is where the circle crosses the positive \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 542, 144, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 542, 384, 560]]<|/det|>
Find angle \(BDC\) in degrees.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 542, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
